Record.Value: Learn how to create an airtight room that can pressurise and depressurise the room.
Welcome back Cadet! Unfortunately due to a pressurization glitch in the airlock, a malfunction occurred causing the catastrophic failure resulting in the airlock being destroyed.

In this lesson we need to create an Airlock for to replace the destroyed one. We will be utilizing vents, pipes, consoles and motherboards.
Let’s start off with a basic airlock setup. First, build the outer {THING:ItemIronFrames} for the airlock it is recommended to use frames as they allow smaller items to be attached to them. You can find the {THING:ItemIronFrames} in the yellow crate.
Now make the {THING:ItemIronFrames} Airtight by finishing them with some Iron plates found in the orange create next to the newly build {THING:ItemIronFrames}.
Use the {THING:ItemKitDoor} from the Yellow crate to build two {THING:StructureCompositeDoor} in the highlighted spots.
Go ahead and finish the construction of the {THING:StructureCompositeDoor}s with {THING:ItemPlasticSheets} and {THING:ItemGlassSheets}.

Next up is to set up a {THING:StructureGasSensor} and a {THING:StructureActiveVent}, a {THING:StructureGasSensor} will tell the console the current atmosphere in the Airlock and is a key component in the airlock, while the {THING:StructureActiveVent} is responsible for pressurising and depressurising the airlock. Build a {THING:StructureGasSensor} and a {THING:StructureActiveVent}.
Build the {THING:StructureGasSensor} in the highlighted location
Build the {THING:StructureActiveVent} in the highlighted location

{THING:ItemKitPipe} are used to carry gas’s from one point to another. We will need to use pipes for the airlock, connect the {THING:StructureActiveVent} to the {THING:StructurePassiveVent} using {THING:ItemKitPipe}.
Note: when building an Airlock you can simply store the grass’s in the pipe itself If you don’t have access to a {THING:StructurePassiveVent}.
Set up a {THING:StructureConsole} by placing it on the wall in the highlighted spot.

To complete the console we need to add a circuit board to it. There are different types of Circuit boards for different situations, In this case, we will are building an Airlock so we need to use the {THING:CircuitboardAirlockControl}, You will also need to use a data disk to allow the {THING:CircuitboardAirlockControl} to be programmed.
Place {THING:ItemGlassSheets} on the {THING:StructureConsole} to complete the Console.

Programming an Airlock is quite easy, Start by turning on the {THING:StructureConsole} simply select the {THING:StructureActiveVent} and {THING:StructureGasSensor}.
When selecting the Airlock ensure the 'INTERIOR' option is selected on the interior door. This can be seen by the Airlocks light turning from Green to Red to indicating which Airlock you're applying the option to. Once the Console has a device selected it will be under its control and will be locked, it won't respond to your interactions aside. When you have successfully completed the Airlock set up the switch on the side of the {THING:StructureConsole} will light up green, you can then remove the data disk from the {THING:StructureConsole}.

Now to test the newly built Airlock, press the “cycle to Interior” button to initialise the pressurization the external pressure must reach at least 101 kPa for the cycle to complete. In some case's the Interior has yet to be pressurised and will never reach the target pressure. If this happens press the “Cancel pressurize” button.
Remove the {THING:ItemDataDisk} and Cycle to interior.

Now that you have a basic Airlock lets make a few upgrades to convert it into an Advanced Airlock. Basic Airlocks will work fine on the moon or planets with no atmosphere but if you want to prevent poisonous gas’s or high/low temperatures entering your base you will need an Advanced airlock. An Advanced airlock pumps any atmosphere out of the airlock before pressurising it again with the desired atmosphere.
To build an advanced airlock you will need another {THING:StructureActiveVent} some more pipes and wire along with the {THING:CircuitboardAdvAirlockControl} to replace the {THING:CircuitboardAirlockControl} from the basic Airlock.
Place another {THING:StructureActiveVent} in the highlighted spot.
Make sure the airlock works by pressing the “cycle to Interior” button.
